thread.title: Quick review sought for data retention act
thread.title_full: Quick review sought for data retention act | Business Spectator

author: Supratim Adhikari
title: Quick review sought for data retention act
text:
The Data Retention Act comes in to effect today and, while bipartisan support in Canberra has seen the law introduced, there is still plenty of dissent simmering below the surface.
As far as the telecommunications providers are concerned, while the law is unlikely to be unwound in a hurry, there is ample scope for the statutory review of the act to be brought forward as quickly as possible.
A review of the act has been scheduled for three years after it becomes fully operational and it is understood that some elements in the telco sector are still hoping that the change of leadership in Canberra could provide an opportunity to unwind some of the more onerous terms of the legislation.
The government’s laws will require telcos to retain customer data for a minimum of two years.
A source told The Australian that many telcos, including one of the big three operators, were still holding out hope that the length of time the data needs to be retained by service providers will be reduced.
However, any amendment to the act will require a swift review and Internet Australia’s chief executive officer Laurie Patton said that three years was just too long to wait given that the flaws in the legislation were apparent.
According to Mr Patton, the implementation process is still “way behind schedule” and the Coalition’s fervour to get data retention legislation across the line is almost certain to have grave consequences for the industry and consumers.
“There is a risk that some, perhaps many, of the smaller ISPs will simply go out of business as a result of this new law, which is especially unfortunate for regional and remote internet consumers who rely on local ISPs because they offer a specialised and personalised services,” he said.
Meanwhile, the cost of implementation continues to vex the industry.
The federal government has allocated $131 million over three years to help telcos meet compliance costs. But there’s still no clarity on how the sum will be divided and whether it will be sufficient.
Mr Patton added that the cost burden of the scheme was almost certain to slug consumers.
“The government’s budgeted amount is well below the likely total costs for the industry and that means that consumers will eventually pay more in internet access fees,” he said.
“It’s extraordinary that an act of this complexity is due to come into effect before anyone knows how much they will receive to cover their costs of compliance.
“International experience has found that data retention is of limited, if any, value in the fight against terrorism, which was the government’s reason for the act.”
This article was first published in The Australian Business Review.
